Packet Pg. 279

Analysis of Law and Policy Affecting the
Cambridge Police Departmentâ€™s
Release of Involved Officersâ€™ Names
After Critical Incidents
July 2023

Police Executive Research Forum
1120 Connecticut Avenue NW, Suite 930
Washington, DC 20036

Attachment: Cambridge - Final - Response to City Manager's Request (CMA 2023 #213 : Final Report from the Police Executive Research

1.21.a

Packet Pg. 280

Overview
At the direction of the Cambridge Police Commissioner, consistent with a Policy Order of
the Cambridge City Council, PERF examined the Cambridge Police Departmentâ€™s (CPD) decision
to withhold the involved officerâ€™s name from the public in the wake of the fatal shooting of Arif
Sayed Faisal on January 4, 2023. PERF was also asked to make policy recommendations to CPD
for releasing involved officersâ€™ names moving forward. CPD welcomed and was fully engaged in
the process.
After examining the applicable law, professional rules, and CPD policy, PERF concludes:
-

-

CPD could have â€” legally and ethically â€” released the officerâ€™s name during the
weeks after the shooting.
Its decision not to do so was based on CPDâ€™s past practices, the statewide practices
of law enforcement agencies in Massachusetts, and the absence of a relevant CPD
policy.
CPDâ€™s ability to release the officerâ€™s name changed when the judge overseeing the
inquest into the matter ordered that no information could be shared publicly until
the inquest is complete; from that point on, CPD could no longer provide the
officerâ€™s name (or any other information) to the public.

Below, PERF presents the relevant procedural history of this incident, analyzes various
rationales law enforcement agencies sometimes cite for withholding an involved officerâ€™s name
from the public and offers policy guidance moving forward.

Background
As of the date of this report, an inquest into the circumstances of the fatal shooting has
not yet concluded; PERF will not receive police reports about the incident until the inquest is
complete. Therefore, the basic facts mentioned in this report are based on consistent news
accounts.
On January 4, 2023, a CPD officer shot and killed Arif Sayed Faisal, a 20-year-old college
student experiencing an apparent mental-health-related issue. The shooting took place after
Mr. Faisal â€” who had reportedly jumped through a glass window and was cutting himself â€”
refused to drop a long knife and advanced toward officers.1 That incident sparked unrest and
demands for transparency by community members.2
Two factors unique to the city of Cambridge (â€œthe cityâ€) and its police department
significantly affected the public response to the incident. First, CPD does not have a body-worn
1

See e.g., https://www.cbsnews.com/boston/news/man-armed-machete-shot-killed-cambridge-police-officer/;
https://www.nbcboston.com/news/local/man-with-machete-prompts-police-response-in-cambridge/2936142/
2
See e.g., https://www.thecrimson.com/article/2023/2/3/sayed-faisal-cover/

Attachment: Cambridge - Final - Response to City Manager's Request (CMA 2023 #213 : Final Report from the Police Executive Research

1.21.a

2

Packet Pg. 281

camera (BWC) program, so there was no video of the incident to release to the public.3 It
appears that the current and previous CPD Commissioners, as well as the CPD union and some
Cambridge city councilors, have supported implementing a BWC program for years, but there
was resistance from others in city government as well as some city residents.4 This tragic
incident has reinvigorated the push for BWCs, and CPD recently took the proactive step of
sending a member of its executive staff to a national meeting focused on BWC best practices.5
The other factor complicating CPDâ€™s response to the incident â€“ and leading to public
frustration - reflects that this was the first officer-involved CPD fatality in more than two
decades. Therefore, the general order governing CPDâ€™s response had not been updated to
reflect some modern transparency trends. Specifically, CPD had no policy language about
whether and when to release the shooting officerâ€™s name.
Not having a policy on name release distinguishes CPD from other national law
enforcement agencies that have implemented such a policy,6 but the same cannot be said of
law enforcement in Massachusetts. While itâ€™s possible that other police agencies in the state
proactively release involved officersâ€™ names within days of fatal critical incidents, PERF was not
able to identify any. This likely presents an opportunity for CPD to be a leader in the state.

CPD Actions Concerning Release of Shooting Officerâ€™s Name
At the time of the fatal shooting, CPDâ€™s policy governing officer-involved shootings had
not been updated since 2008, and its only reference to the release of an officerâ€™s name occurred
in the context of how officers could guard against telephone harassment if their names were
somehow released to the public:
â€œIn order to protect against crank or abusive calls, officers should be advised to
have phone calls answered by another person for several days if their names
are released to the public.â€7
Because CPD had no policy requiring the release of the officerâ€™s name within a specified
time frame - or prohibiting it - CPD was free from the inception to make its own choice about
whether to release the shooting officerâ€™s name. When CPD decided not to release the name in
the immediate aftermath of the shooting, the public was left wondering why CPD did not
disclose information that other agencies routinely release expeditiously.
For instance, a 2016 PERF review of agencies in the Washington, DC area found that
even then, many departments had updated their policies to provide for the expedited release
3

https://www.masslive.com/news/2023/01/cambridge-officials-have-always-wanted-body-cameras-for-police-sowhy-dont-they-still-have-them.html
4
https://myemail.constantcontact.com/It-s-Happening-in-Cambridge.html?soid=1114093348634&aid=k_LMjHl6CVE
5
https://www.policeforum.org/index.php?option=com_jevents&task=icalevent.detail&evid=75
6
To be sure, CPD is a progressive agency, leading the .
7
No. 402, Post-Shooting Incident Guidelines, Section (V)(B)(9). The Orderâ€™s apparent focus on landline telephone
harassment and its silence about potential abuse via social media are further evidence that it was outdated.

Attachment: Cambridge - Final - Response to City Manager's Request (CMA 2023 #213 : Final Report from the Police Executive Research

1.21.a

3

Packet Pg. 282

of an involved officerâ€™s name after a critical incident. These included: Anne Arundel County
(MD) Police Department â€“ within 24 hours; Baltimore (MD) Police Department â€“ within 48
hours; Howard County (MD) Police Department â€“ â€œAs quickly as possibleâ€; Montgomery County
(MD) Police Department â€“ within 24 hours; Prince Georgeâ€™s County (MD) Police Department â€“
within 24 hours; and Prince William County (VA) Police Department â€“ within three to five days.
PERF determined that CPD withheld the officerâ€™s name based on past practice within the
department (concerning non-fatal incidents and other acts of potential misconduct), as well as
the current practice of other Massachusetts law enforcement agencies. Those factors, as well as
a belief that it was not permitted to release the name without the express consent of the local
prosecutor, rather than a desire to keep information hidden from the public, steered CPDâ€™s
response in the weeks after the shooting.
After the local prosecutor announced an inquest8 (a practice authorized in
Massachusetts in which a judge investigates the circumstances of a death to determine
whether a crime took place),9 CPD informed PERF that it was not releasing the officerâ€™s name
because, according to the local prosecutor, the judge presiding over the inquest had issued an
order directing that no entity could release information about the incident until the inquest was
complete.10
To be sure, the judgeâ€™s order precludes CPD from releasing the name until the inquest is
complete. But as noted above, nothing in law or policy automatically prevented CPD from
releasing the name before the judge issued that order.
On May 15, 2023, the Cambridge City Manager, consistent with a City Council Policy
Order, requested that CPD work with PERF to establish a policy on the release of the names of
officers involved in any use of force incident resulting in injury or death, â€œincluding
retroactively.â€11

Rationales for Withholding Names
To prevent confusion about these issues as CPD develops its new policy, this section
addresses some rationales law enforcement agencies cite when withholding officersâ€™ names
from the public. Going forward, CPD should begin with the presumption that it will release the
officerâ€™s name within a specific period of time, and then thoughtfully consider whether reasons
exist that would legitimately and in good faith justify withholding it from the public.

8

https://www.bostonglobe.com/2023/02/23/metro/middlesex-da-announces-inquest-into-fatal-cambridge-policeshooting-college-student/
9
https://www.mass.gov/doc/frequently-asked-questions-about-inquests/download
10
PERF also reviewed a press release issued by the Middlesex District Attorney on February 23, 2023, indicating
that by order of the Court, no further details would be provided about the incident until the inquest process had
been completed.

City of Cambridge Calendar Item #2, May 22, 2023.

Attachment: Cambridge - Final - Response to City Manager's Request (CMA 2023 #213 : Final Report from the Police Executive Research

1.21.a

4

Packet Pg. 283

Public Records Law Exemptions
Every state including Massachusetts,12 as well as the federal government, has a publicrecords-access law (i.e., freedom of information or sunshine law). Public access laws stand for
the principle that records of public entities, including police agencies, are assumed to be
available to the public unless a specific exemption exists that allows the record to be wholly or
partially withheld.13 Absent such an exemption, the records, and information contained in them
(such as an officerâ€™s name) are public.
In terms of police agencies and officer-involved shootings, proactively releasing
information that the public would be entitled to know by virtue of the stateâ€™s public access
law is an act of good faith that reinforces public trust. But as noted above, there are
exemptions to public access and agencies generally invoke one of the following to avoid
releasing an officerâ€™s name after an officer-involved shooting.
i. Pending Investigation
Public records laws generally contain some type of â€œpending investigationâ€ exemption.
However, the fact that a matter is pending investigation, by itself, does not justify the blanket
denial of all information about the incident until the underlying investigation is complete.
Instead, most agencies can legitimately withhold information about a pending investigation only
if its release would interfere with the pending investigation itself or law enforcementâ€™s ability to
function in general.
The Massachusetts Public Record Law is no different. Investigatory materials are defined
as materials:
â€œâ€¦ compiled out of the public view by law enforcement or other investigatory
officials the disclosure of which â€¦ would probably so prejudice the possibility of
effective law enforcement that such disclosure would not be in the public
interest.â€14
According to the Massachusetts Supreme Court, police officers occupy positions of â€œspecial
public trustâ€ that favor transparency of public records about them.15 It would therefore be a
heavy burden to show that releasing an officerâ€™s name, standing alone, would run so counter to
public interest that withholding it would be justified by the Public Records Law.

12

Massachusetts Public Records Law, Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 4 Â§ 7(26) et. seq.
Glavin, W.F., Secretary of the Commonwealth, Guide to the Massachusetts Public Records Law (2020) SB101Public-Records-Law-Guide.pdf (frcog.org)
14
Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 4 Â§ 7(26)(f) (emphasis added)
15
See Bos. Globe Media Partners, LLC v. Department of Criminal Justice Info. Servs., 484 Mass. 279 (2020).
13

Attachment: Cambridge - Final - Response to City Manager's Request (CMA 2023 #213 : Final Report from the Police Executive Research

1.21.a

5

Packet Pg. 284

Absent a good-faith reason why releasing an officerâ€™s name would prejudice CPDâ€™s ability
to conduct its work effectively, CPD should release involved officersâ€™ names proactively moving
forward. (See the â€œPolicy Recommendationsâ€ section below for specifics.)
ii. Safety of the Officer
The Massachusetts Public Records Law, like other public access laws, also contains an
exemption allowing agencies to withhold records (and information within them) if release
would endanger or threaten a person or personsâ€™ safety.16 After critical incidents, police
agencies have occasionally withheld officersâ€™ names on this basis as well.
PERF does not minimize the importance of officer safety, especially in the highly charged
environment that can follow critical incidents. But blanket denials based on safety, with no
corresponding threat assessment, are hollow. As detailed below in the Policy
Recommendations, PERF believes that moving forward, CPD should engage in safety
assessments after critical incidents and, in the absence of specific threats that would justify
withholding the names, release them within a pre-determined time frame, after informing the
officer and implementing safety provisions.
In reviewing these Public Records Law exemptions, PERF does not suggest that in any
given case, these or other exemptions could not be validly invoked to withhold an officerâ€™s
name or other information. The point, rather, is that invoking an exemption as a blanket
rationale to avoid public release, without corresponding facts that support that action, runs
counter to principles of transparency and can erode public trust.
Rules of Professional Conduct
At some point prior to the judgeâ€™s order, CPD advised PERF of its belief that it could not
release the officerâ€™s name according to the Massachusetts Rules of Professional Conduct. Those
rules govern attorney conduct but can affect law enforcement indirectly. Specifically, Rule
3.8(f)(2) requires that prosecutors â€œtake reasonable steps to prevent â€¦ law enforcement
personnelâ€ from making statements that the prosecutor would be prohibited from making. But
again, in this case, the release of the officerâ€™s name would not have violated the Rules of
Professional Conduct.
According to Rule 3.8, prosecutors (and members of law enforcement working with
them) shall refrain from making statements â€œthat have a substantial likelihood of heightening
public condemnation of the accusedâ€ or â€œmaterially prejudicingâ€ a proceeding.17 In other words,
it is incumbent on the prosecutor and law enforcement to refrain from making statements that
would be expected to prejudice public opinion against a person accused of a crime or,
presumably, a person against whom a criminal charge is possible.

16
17

Massachusetts Public Records Law, Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 4 Â§ 7(26)(n).
See also Mass.R.Prof.C. 3.6(a)

Attachment: Cambridge - Final - Response to City Manager's Request (CMA 2023 #213 : Final Report from the Police Executive Research

1.21.a

6

Packet Pg. 285

These rules are no different from those promulgated by President Obamaâ€™s Task Force on
21st-Century Policing, which called for increased transparency when law enforcement agencies
communicate with the public after critical incidents.18 The Task Force recommended that
information be released early and updated regularly if it could be done â€œwithout compromising
the integrity of the investigation or anyoneâ€™s rights.â€
Unless CPD can, in good faith, after consultation with the prosecutor, articulate why
releasing the name of the officer in a critical incident would prejudice public opinion such that
the officerâ€™s rights are affected, or show that release of the name would credibly compromise
the investigation, PERF recommends that the agency proactively release it going forward.
In this case, the public knew early on that an officer fired a weapon and killed a man. It is
difficult to imagine how replacing â€œan officerâ€ with the officerâ€™s name might have prejudiced the
outcome of the investigation.
The Commonwealthâ€™s Right of Privacy Statute
Massachusetts law provides, â€œA person shall have a right against unreasonable,
substantial or serious interference with [that personâ€™s] privacy.â€19 Violation of the statute occurs
when â€œfacts of a highly personal or intimate natureâ€ are disclosed about a person, â€œwith no
legitimate reason for doing so.â€20
Here, the information that the CPD is considering releasing about officers, following
critical incidents, is their names â€“ not their addresses, private medical information, or any
personal or intimate details about their lives. As noted above, the Massachusetts Supreme
Court has held that police officers occupy positions of trust that lean in favor of transparency
regarding their records.21 And, far from having no legitimate interest in releasing the name, CPD
and the city have a very compelling reason to do so â€“ being transparent with the public they
serve.
Accordingly, it does not appear that Massachusettsâ€™s Privacy Statute provides a
justification to automatically withhold an officerâ€™s name from the public after a critical incident.
Summary
The statutes and rules highlighted above allow agencies to delay the release of
information, or withhold it altogether, under certain circumstances; they should not be used as
blanket justifications to keep information from the public. As detailed below, PERF recommends
that CPD make determinations about whether to release information - such as the officerâ€™s

18

Final Report of the Presidentâ€™s Task Force on 21st Century Policing (May 2015),
https://cops.usdoj.gov/pdf/taskforce/taskforce_finalreport.pdf.
19
Mass. Gen. Laws c. 214 Â§ 1B.
20
Alexander v. Clarke, 0905456H (Mass. Super. Mass. Super May3, 2011).
21
Bos. Globe v. Department of Criminal Justice, supra.

Attachment: Cambridge - Final - Response to City Manager's Request (CMA 2023 #213 : Final Report from the Police Executive Research

1.21.a

7

Packet Pg. 286

name in a critical incident â€“ on a case-by-case basis, and after thoughtful deliberation, with a
presumption that the information will be made public.

Policy Recommendations
The new critical incident policy that CPD is drafting will greatly assist the agency, the
public, and officers, by establishing consistent timelines and clear expectations. The policy
should specify that the release of information such as an officerâ€™s name, will take place within
prescribed timeframes â€” subject to relevant legal and professional standards, including the
Massachusetts Public Records Law and Massachusetts Rules of Professional Conduct.
PERF recommends that the Cambridge Police Commissioner, in consultation with
appropriate staff and the prosecuting authority, should assume that certain information will be
released to the public unless a legitimate, good-faith reason exists to withhold it. PERF
recommends that CPDâ€™s new policy include language capturing the principles below:
1. Unless a specific, articulable, good-faith reason exists not to do so, within 24-36
hours of an officer-involved critical incident CPD should publicly disclose:
- Preliminary facts about the incident, including, at a minimum, where and when
it took place and the number of people injured or deceased.
- Preliminary information about the officer(s) involved, such as length of time as
an officer and length of time with CPD (if the officer transferred from another
agency), rank, assignment, prior uses of force, and status (e.g., modified
assignment or leave pending the investigative outcome.)
- An estimated time frame for how and when further information will be
released, including the officerâ€™s name.
â€¢ CPD policy should specify that the agency will begin its threat assessment
to determine whether a credible risk to officer safety exists during this
time.
â€¢ CPD must consider and begin to address officer wellness during this time
(see #2 below).
The above principles balance the publicâ€™s desire for information with the CPDâ€™s need
to consult with staff and the prosecuting authority to identify whether any genuine
issues exist that conflict with the presumption of information release. They also
present a timeframe within which CPD must begin its threat assessment and provide
the public and the involved officer with its good-faith expectation about when the
name will be (presumptively) released.
2. CPD should, within two to five days of an officer-involved critical incident, publicly
disclose the name of the involved officer(s) unless circumstances exist that justify
not releasing that information.

Attachment: Cambridge - Final - Response to City Manager's Request (CMA 2023 #213 : Final Report from the Police Executive Research

1.21.a

8

Packet Pg. 287

-

-

-

This two-to-five-day period allows CPD to conduct a meaningful threat
assessment.
If the assessment reveals no credible threat to safety, CPD should release the
name within two days. If there are genuine threat indicators, the assessment
should continue. And if, after five days, a credible risk persists, the officerâ€™s name
may be legitimately withheld for as long as the risk remains. CPD should,
however, communicate why it is withholding the name from the public. And if
the threat abates, the name should be released.
If circumstances other than officer safety justify withholding the officerâ€™s name
(and this will generally be rare) CPD should broadly communicate that to the
public (e.g., â€œRelease would impede CPDâ€™s ability to conduct this [or other]
investigation(s).â€). CPD should also be prepared to defend that justification after
the investigation is complete.
Before an officerâ€™s name is released publicly, CPD must ensure that the involved
officer has been notified and given access to departmental services. These
include mental health assistance, peer support, and a full explanation of the
officerâ€™s rights.

Conclusion
The issue of whether and when CPD should have released the involved officerâ€™s name in
this fatal incident ultimately stemmed from the lack of a clear protocol and will be mitigated
once CPD updates its policy.
Notwithstanding the lack of policy, if, after examining the issues outlined above, CPD had
chosen to release the officerâ€™s name, it could have legitimately done so â€” until the judge issued
the order directing that no information could be shared until the inquest was complete. As of
this writing, the inquest is continuing.
CPD is an agency that has, over time, demonstrated leadership in several key areas of
reform, including juvenile diversion programs,22 and trauma-informed police practices.23 CPD
now appears poised to lead the state of Massachusetts in developing a policy to release officersâ€™
names after critical incidents.

Packet Pg. 293

1.24

August 7, 2023
To the Honorable, the City Council:

I am hereby requesting the transfer of $46,510.75 in unexpended Public Investment balances
from capital projects related to equipment, that have been completed, the balances from which
are now available for redistribution to other related projects.
Periodically, the City reviews capital projects with available balances due to unexpended funds
at the time the project was complete.
I am requesting that these balances be combined and transferred to the Public Investment Fund
Finance Extraordinary Expenditures Account. These funds will support capital expenditures
related to equipment purchases.
Very truly yours,

Yi-An Huang
City Manager

from which are now available for redistribution to other related projects.

Packet Pg. 295

1.26

August 7, 2023
To the Honorable, the City Council:

In response to Council Order No. O-8 of February 10, 2020, which is attached hereto for your
reference, the City has inquired as to the possibility of acquiring the property at 450 Concord
Avenue, owned by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts (â€œCommonwealthâ€) and utilized by the
National Guard Armory of Cambridge, adjacent to the Tobin School. The Commonwealth is
unwilling to sell the entire parcel to the City, but has expressed interest in selling a portion of the
property. The portion of the property consists of 30,752 square feet of the Armory property that
is adjacent to the Callanan Fields and Tobin School (â€œPropertyâ€), as shown on the attached map
as â€œParcel Bâ€. Currently the Property is used for military purposes by the Commonwealth. The
Property could be used to expand the sports fields, create school learning areas, and increase
open space and walking paths near the Tobin School and Callanan Fields. The City has obtained
an appraisal showing the value of the Property to be $5,380,000.00.
In order for the City to purchase of the Property, the Commonwealth requires that a special act
be passed allowing the Commonwealth to dispose of the Property and for it to be sold to the
City. The Commonwealth has proposed legislation allowing the Commissioner of Capital Asset
and Maintenance to convey the Property to the City in an amount to be determined by an
independent professional appraiser, which will be paid for by the City. A copy of the proposed
legislation, which has been reviewed and edited by City staff, is attached hereto.
I request that the City Council vote to allow the City Clerk to transmit the proposed legislation to
the Cityâ€™s legislative delegation for passage before the legislature. If the legislation and
independent appraisal are approved, then I will bring the proposal before the City Council to
approve the purchase under the terms offered by the Commonwealth.
Very truly yours,

Yi-An Huang
City Manager

Packet Pg. 297

1.26.b

OIN CITY COUNCIL
February 10, 2020
COUNCILLOR NOLAN
VICE MAYOR MALLON
COUNCILLOR MCGOVERN
WHEREAS:

As part of the Tobin Montessori/Vassal Lane Upper Schools Reconstruction Project,
conceptual designs have been released; and

WHEREAS:

There has been a concerted effort to find space for Elementary and Upper School
enrollment expansion, additional much-needed programmatic elements and increased
capacity for preschool enrollment, while at the same time preserving the need for open
space, ensuring adequate traffic flow and appropriate site circulation has been
challenging; and

WHEREAS:

The National Guard Armory of Cambridge, located at 450 Concord Avenue, adjacent
to the Tobin Montessori/Vassal Lane Upper Schools campus, presents a potential
opportunity for the City to resolve community concerns that the proposed
reconstruction designs would negatively impact the amount of available green space,
and the flow of school traffic; and

WHEREAS:

The Armory site, which is owned by the state (purchased from Cambridge in 1957), is
currently underutilized; and

WHEREAS:

A 2018 assessment of the Armory site by the state shows the need for significant
investment to keep the site up to code; and

WHEREAS:

The City Manager has sent a letter to the State Quartermaster expressing Cambridgeâ€™s
strong interest in acquiring the Armory site; now therefore be it

ORDERED:

That the City Council go on record strongly supporting the City Managerâ€™s request to
purchase the National Guard Armory of Cambridge, and go on record as urging the
Cityâ€™s Delegation in the State Legislature to work to determine if the state will take the
steps necessary to allow the City to purchase the entire site, to be for permanent public
use in perpetuity by the City to address community driven needs; and be it further

ORDERED:

That the City Clerk be and hereby is requested to forward suitably engrossed copies of
this policy order to the Cityâ€™s Delegation in the State Legislature on behalf of the entire
City Council.

Attachment: Armory Policy Order O of February 10, 2020 (CMA 2023 #218 : Armory 450 Concord Avenue)

City of Cambridge

Packet Pg. 298

1.26.c

An Act authorizing the commissioner of capital asset management and maintenance to convey a certain
parcel of land to the city of Cambridge.

SECTION 1. Notwithstanding sections 32 to 37, inclusive, of chapter 7C of the General Laws or any
general or special law to the contrary, the commissioner of capital asset management and maintenance,
in consultation with the military division, may convey a portion of the parcel of land located at 406
Concord avenue in the city of Cambridge currently used for military purposes to the city of Cambridge to
be used for school and other municipal purposes and for all purposes and uses accessory thereto. The
parcel is a portion of the land described in deeds recorded in the Middlesex South registry of deeds in
book 9038, page 388 and book 9733, page 1. The parcel is approximately 30,752 square feet and is
shown as â€œParcel â€˜Bâ€™â€ on a plan entitled, â€œApproval Not Required Plan for 450 Concord Avenue
Cambridge Massachusetts,â€ dated April 2, 2021, which plan is on file with the division of capital asset
management and maintenance. The commissioner of capital asset management and maintenance may
determine the exact boundaries of the parcel prior to conveyance. The parcels shall be conveyed by
deed without warranties or representations by the commonwealth.
SECTION 2. The deed or other instrument conveying the parcel to the city of Cambridge shall provide
that the parcel shall be used solely for school and other municipal purposes and for all purposes and
uses accessory thereto and shall include a reversionary clause that stipulates that if the parcel ceases at
any time to be used for the allowed purpose set forth in this act, title to the parcel shall, at the election
of the commonwealth, revert to the commonwealth. The reversionary clause shall be enforceable
notwithstanding the time limit set forth in section 7 of chapter 184A of the General Laws.
SECTION 3. The consideration for the conveyance of the parcel pursuant to section 1 shall be the fair
market value of the parcel as determined by the commissioner of capital asset management and
maintenance based upon an independent professional appraisal for the use of the parcel as restricted
pursuant to section 2. The appraisal shall be prepared in accordance with the usual and customary
professional appraisal practices by a qualified appraiser. The commissioner shall submit any appraisals
to the inspector general for review and comment. The inspector general shall review and approve any
such appraisals; provided, however, that the review shall include an examination of the methodology
utilized for the appraisals. The inspector general shall prepare a report of the review and file the report
with the commissioner of capital asset management and maintenance. The commissioner shall submit
copies of the appraisals and the inspector generalâ€™s review and approval and comments, if any, to the
senate and house committees on ways and means and the joint committee on state administration and
regulatory oversight not less than 15 days before the execution of any documents effecting the transfers
authorized in this act.
SECTION 4. Pursuant to section 113 of chapter 33 of the General Laws, any monetary payments made to
the commonwealth as a result of the conveyance authorized by this act shall be deposited in the real
property expendable trust established by the secretary of public safety and security for the military
division pursuant to section 6 of chapter 6A of the General Laws and 801 CMR 50.00 et seq.

Attachment: Armory Legislation Special Act 8-7-23 (CMA 2023 #218 : Armory 450 Concord Avenue)

Whereas, The deferred operation of this act would tend to defeat its purpose, which is to authorize
forthwith the conveyance of certain property to the city of Cambridge, therefore it is hereby declared to
be an emergency law, necessary for the immediate preservation of the public convenience.

Packet Pg. 299

SECTION 5. Notwithstanding any general or special law to the contrary, the city of Cambridge shall be
responsible for all costs and expenses of any transaction authorized by this act as determined by the
commissioner of capital asset management and maintenance including, but not limited to, the costs of
any engineering, surveys, appraisals, title examinations, recording fees and deed preparation related to
the conveyance of the parcel authorized in section 1. Upon the recording of the deed conveying the
parcels to the city of Cambridge, the city shall record a plan showing the boundaries of the parcel and
deliver a copy of the plan to the division of capital asset management and maintenance and the division
shall keep the plan on file.

In City Council August 7, 2023.
Adopted by a yea and nay vote:Yeas 9; Nays 0; Absent 0.
Attest:- Diane P. LeBlanc, City Clerk
A true copy;

ATTEST:Diane P. LeBlanc
City Clerk

Attachment: Armory Legislation Special Act 8-7-23 (CMA 2023 #218 : Armory 450 Concord Avenue)

Packet Pg. 302

2.1

City of Cambridge

O-5
Calendar Item # 1
FIRST IN COUNCIL
June 26, 2023

COUNCILLOR NOLAN
COUNCILLOR ZONDERVAN
COUNCILLOR MCGOVERN
VICE MAYOR MALLON
WHEREAS:

The city is conducting a business impact study related to the installation of separated
bicycle lanes, which began in 2004 with the installation of the cityâ€™s first separated
bike lane, and accelerated in 2016 with the introduction of quickbuild separated bicycle
lanes; and

WHEREAS:

It is crucial to ensure that the study utilizes accurate, objective, and reliable data from
before and after installation to assess the positive or negative economic impacts on
businesses from separated bicycle lane installations; and

WHEREAS:

The goal is to improve the implementation of separated bicycle lane projects so that
positive impacts on local businesses are enhanced and negative impacts are avoided or
mitigated; now therefore be it

Packet Pg. 303

2.1

ORDERED:

That the City Manager be and hereby is requested to consider the following measures
to enhance the aforementioned business impact study:
1. Prioritize the utilization of objective data sources on economic impact over
subjective or survey-based data sources: (a) Partner with the state revenue
agency to conduct sales tax data analysis, avoiding privacy issues; (b) Obtain
transaction or business utilization data from third-party vendors; (c) Examine
the long-term impacts on vacancy rates and rent prices on earlier bike lane
projects, including Cambridge St, Brattle St, Western Ave, and earlier
segments of Mass Ave, avoiding potential distortions caused by the pandemic;
2. To the extent that subjective or survey-based data sources are used, work to
minimize statistical bias (anchoring bias, reporting bias, etc.): (a) Consult with
a working group of experts, such as quantitative social scientists and policy
evaluation researchers from local academic institutions, to ensure the
utilization of best practices; (b) Measure customer perceptions and preferences
for the retail environment through customer intercept surveys; (c) Consult with
business staff to understand and assess their priorities, preferences, and
concerns, in addition to consultations with business owners;
3. In addition to measuring impacts, aggregate ideas for how to improve the
implementation of separated bicycle lanes along commercial corridors to
enhance the business environment: (a) If surveys are conducted, solicit broader
feedback regarding ways to improve the implementation and operation of bike
lane projects, potential mitigations for regions with newly implemented bike
lanes, and curb-use management strategies, including loading, short-term/longterm parking, and outdoor dining; (b) Estimate the potential impacts of
changes to parking policies and dynamic meter pricing to ensure sufficient
parking availability;
and be it further

ORDERED:

That the City Manager be and hereby is requested to report back to the City Council on
these matters by September 1, 2023, outlining the proposed improvements to the
business impact study for separated bicycle lanes, including the incorporation of
objective data sources, collaboration with external partners, and strategies for gathering
feedback and ideas from businesses.

Packet Pg. 304

2.1

06/26/23

Packet Pg. 305

2.2

City of Cambridge

O-7
Calendar Item # 2
FIRST IN COUNCIL
June 26, 2023
August 7, 2023

COUNCILLOR ZONDERVAN
COUNCILLOR CARLONE
WHEREAS:

It has come to the attention of the City Council that the Philippine Human Rights Act
(PHRA) has been reintroduced in the US House of Representatives as H.R. 1433, but a
companion bill has yet to be filed in the US Senate; and

WHEREAS:

PHRA seeks to suspend all security (military) funding and sales from the US to
the Philippines until such time that the human rights crisis in the Philippines has
been properly addressed, including by (but not limited to):
â€¢ Investigating and prosecuting members of the military and police forces
who are credibly found to have violated human rights
â€¢ Withdrawing the military from domestic policy
â€¢ Establishing protections of the rights of trade unionists, journalists,
human rights defenders, indigenous persons, small farmers, LGBTQ+
activists, and critics of the government
â€¢ Taking steps to guarantee a judicial system that is capable of
investigating, prosecuting, and bringing to justice members of the police
and military who have committed human rights abuses
â€¢ Fully complying with any and all audits or investigations regarding the
improper use of security aid; and

WHEREAS:

Since 2016, the Philippines has been undergoing a national human rights crisis,
precipitated by former President Rodrigo Duterteâ€™s brutal Drug War, involving ExtraJudicial Killings (EJKs) of over 30,000 people, including urban poor, farmers,
peasants, indigenous, environmental activists, and government critics, and others
purported to be involved in drug activity; and

WHEREAS:

Other Human Rights Violations in the Philippines, largely attributed to the
government, include: forced disappearances, torture, red-tagging of civilians and
activists, silencing of the freedom of expression and the press, and state violence and
theft against indigenous peoples; and

WHEREAS:

These human rights abuses are often committed by the Philippine National
Police (PNP) and the Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP), which receive
taxpayer-funded financial assistance from the U.S., and it is estimated that
6,242 individuals were killed by the PNP and the Philippine Drug Enforcement
Agency in anti-drug operations from July 1, 2016, to May 31, 2022 in addition
to the 30,000 EJKs; and

Packet Pg. 306

2.2

WHEREAS:

Very few â€œdrug warâ€ killings have been investigated by Philippine authorities, only a
handful of casesâ€”12 out of thousandsâ€”are in varying stages of investigation by
police or active review by prosecutors, and to date, there is only one case, the videorecorded murder of 17-year-old student Kian delos Santos in August 2017, which
resulted in the conviction of police officers; and

WHEREAS:

Current President of the Philippines Ferdinand Marcos Jr. has maintained that he will
continue the War on Drugs, the regime no longer reports on killings by government
actors, and killings by the PNP and AFP have continued under his regime with over 90
drug-related killings since Marcos took office in September 2022; and

WHEREAS:

Marcos Jr. has maintained the Philippinesâ€™ withdrawal from the International Criminal
Court (ICC) and will not cooperate with the ICCâ€™s investigation into the Crimes
Against Humanity during the previous Presidential Administration between 2016 and
2022; and

WHEREAS:

Marcos Jr. is the son of the former President and dictator of the Philippines, Ferdinand
Marcos Sr., who enacted Martial Law in the Philippines between September 1972 and
January 1981 and committed egregious human rights violations including amassing a
private fortune of US $10 billion by plundering from the Filipino people during his
time as president; and

WHEREAS:

The U.S. has given over US $1.14 billion in military assistance to the Philippines since
2015, which means that U.S. taxpayer dollars have contributed extensively to human
rights violations in the Philippines; now therefore be it

RESOLVED:

That the City Council go on record in enthusiastic support of H.R.1433, the Philippine
Human Rights Act, and in urging Representatives Katherine Clark and Ayanna
Pressley to co-sponsor the existing bill; and be it further

RESOLVED:

That the City Council go on record in urging Senators Ed Markey and Elizabeth
Warren to file a companion bill to H.R.1433 in the US Senate; and be it further

RESOLVED:

That the City Clerk be and hereby is requested to forward suitably engrossed copies of
this resolution to Cambridgeâ€™s entire Congressional Delegation on behalf of the entire
City Council.
In City Council August 7, 2023.
Adopted by a yea and nay vote:Yeas 7; Nays 0; Present 2; Absent 0
Attest:- Diane P. LeBlanc, City Clerk
A true copy;

ATTEST:Diane P. LeBlanc,
City Clerk

Packet Pg. 308

City of Cambridge

O-8
Calendar Item # 3
FIRST IN COUNCIL
June 26, 2023

COUNCILLOR SIMMONS
COUNCILLOR TONER
WHEREAS:

The City Council is currently working towards establishing a more aggressive timeline
to implement our BEUDO requirements, which would mandate that the majority of
buildings falling under the scope of this ordinance would need to fully comply by
2035, rather than 2050; and

WHEREAS:

Over the course of many months of hearings and public discussions on this matter, it
has become clear that for some, it will be a confusing and potentially costly process to
fully comply with this more aggressive timeline, and it would be prudent for the City
to find tangible ways to assist residents in meeting that goal; and

WHEREAS:

One such method would be to establish a BEUDO Compliance Advisory Board, which
â€“ similar to the Implementation Advisory Committee that was established to assist
businesses comply with the smoking ban enacted two decades ago â€“ would be
available to advise residents on how to best adapt to the new law, how to better
understand the law, how to troubleshoot areas of concern, and to otherwise assist
residents who may be in need of greater, more comprehensive support throughout the
process; now therefore be it

ORDERED:

That the City Manager be and hereby is requested to direct the appropriate City staff to
establish a BEUDO Compliance Advisory Board designed to meet the above stated
goals of assisting residents with complying with the forthcoming adjusted BEUDO
timeline, and to report back to the City Council on progress made towards this goal at
the August 7, 2023 City Council meeting.

That the Commissioner of Public Works is hereby authorized to grant a permit for the
installation of a curb cut (1 of 4) at the premises numbered 200 Main Street,
Cambridge, Massachusetts; said authorization is conditioned upon use of material
specified by the Department of Public Works and upon permit requirements being met,
including an ADA compliant design.

In City Council August 7, 2023.
Adopted by a yea and nay vote:Yeas 7; Nays 0; Absent 2.
Attest:- Diane P. LeBlanc, City Clerk
A true copy;

ATTEST:Diane P. LeBlanc,
City Clerk

3.8

City of Cambridge
ORDERED:

APP-8
FIRST IN COUNCIL
August 7, 2023

That, in accordance with the provisions of an ordinance relative to placing and
maintaining signs, the Commissioner of Public Works be and hereby is authorized to
grant a permit to Vico Style for a projecting blade sign at the premises numbered 73
Mt. Auburn Street, Cambridge, Massachusetts. Provided that, before erecting the
above named projecting sign the petitioner shall file with the City Clerk a bond in the
sum of Two Thousand ($2,000.00) dollars, conditioned to save harmless the City of
Cambridge from all claims for damages arising from the installation, maintenance and
use of said projecting blade sign.

In City Council August 7, 2023.
Adopted by a yea and nay vote:Yeas 7; Nays 0; Absent 2.
Attest:- Diane P. LeBlanc, City Clerk
A true copy;

ATTEST:Diane P. LeBlanc,
City Clerk

Tonight's BEUDO Amendments

Dear City Councilors:
I greatly appreciate your support thus far for the effective set of amendments to the Building Energy Use Disclosure
Ordinance.
As a concerned parent living in this city of booming development our shared climate concern remains a daunting
concern. Our city should continue to be doing everything it can to reduce greenhouse emissions swiftly and equitably.
We need all the support presently available at the state and national levels; we need to push our building owners,
especially institutional buildings, to do their part.
Please speak for our many concerned citizens, myself included, that you pass a final version of the BEUDO amendments
that is adequate and strong.
One specific suggested modification to tonight's amendments is the inclusion of a 2030 Net Zero target for new large
lab, scientific research, and medical facilities. Without this provision, emissions from these could undermine the
greenhouse gas reductions that BEUDO is designed to
bring about.
My Sincere Appreciation,
Agnes Murphy Criss
76 Antrim ST

Attachment: Agnes Murphy Criss Tonight's BEUDO Amendments (COM 1529 #2023 : A communication was received from Agnes Murphy Criss)

reports each day. And, aside from those major events â€“ hurricanes, fires, etc. â€“ that
appear in the news, the extensive damage to peopleâ€™s health from climate change is
becoming increasingly apparent. Cambridge and others must act now!

Zondervan, Quinton; Mallon, Alanna; Azeem, Burhan; Nolan, Patricia; Carlone, Dennis;
Simmons, Denise; Siddiqui, Sumbul; McGovern, Marc
City Manager; City Clerk
Policy Order #5

Dear Councilors,

I write concerning PO#5 which prescribes in extraordinary detail a study to determine the economic
impact on businesses of your plans for separated bike lanes through major commercial areas. I was
under the impression that your body had already executed a contract with the Volpe Center to study the
same issue by this Fall.

As a citizen who feels steamrolled by the juggernaut adoption and implementation of the CSO, I am also
confused by the aforementioned policy order. Many Cambridge residents have been calling for
transparency and accountability regarding the CSO implementation. Then it appeared that the Volpe
study was one small step in the right direction. But now, it appears that the council
is preparing to make the implementation of the Volpe study more difficult if not impossible with the
introduction of PO#5. It is completely unclear how this new PO inter-relates with or effects the Volpe
study.

I strongly urge the council to stop this chaotic and confusing direction and to let the Volpe study
proceed. Please vote against PO#5.

Thank you,
Barbara Anthony

Sent from my iPhone

Attachment: Barbara Anthony Policy Order #5 (COM 1533 #2023 : A communication was received from Barbara Anthony)

Support for Strong BEUDO Amendments

Dear City Councillors:
Thank you so much for your support for a strong set of amendments to the Building Energy Use Disclosure
Ordinance (BEUDO)! I believe that what you are doing is historic, and nationally important. Although
Cambridge is not the only city in the country setting greenhouse gas emissions standards for buildings (New
York City, Boston, San Francisco, Washington D.C. and St. Louis are examples), Cambridgeâ€™s BEUDO will
have some of the earliest compliance dates. This reflects the true urgency of the climate crisis!
I appreciate the work that CDD staff and the Council have done to move the BEUDO amendments forward!
The refinements to the use of Verified Carbon Credits are great â€“ they will allow some flexibility while meeting
real carbon reduction goals as locally as possible.
I urge you to continue to push our large building owners, especially the institutional ones, to do their part. Is it
possible to include a 2030 net zero target for new large lab, scientific research, and medical facilities by
allowing them to develop Hardship Compliance Plans based on actual technological barriers and hardships? Is
it possible to keep the 2030 net zero target for all â€œNew Covered Propertiesâ€ without pre-empting the state
building code by having a fee, rather than penalty, structure?
Please stay the course to pass a final version of the BEUDO amendments that is strong, vigorous, and
adequate to the urgency at hand!

Please finalize the amendment to require all BEUDO buildings over 25,000 square feet to be net-zero by 2035, with only
local offsets permitted. Please also support the inclusion of a 2030 net zero target for new large lab, scientific research,
and medical facilities, to prevent emissions from these buildings from undermining the greenhouse gas reductions
BEUDO is designed to bring about.
We cannot allow this situation to continue to be out of control any longer. Apparently, greenhouse gas emissions from
large commercial and institutional buildings in the city increased by almost 30% from 2011 to 2019.
Affected parties can absorb the costs. Please donâ€™t assume otherwise. We have waited far too long to fully address
global warming. New England is warming faster than other parts of the U.S.
Cambridge has an exemplary history including its involvement in founding this nation. Letâ€™s honor that history by taking
decisive action to slow climate change on a schedule much more appropriate to the severe time limits outlined by the
IPCC than the alternative. The benefits in livability, health, economic justice and additional years at net-zero will far
outweigh the costs.
Thank you!

David Buck, 307 Elm St. Unit 3, Cambridge 02139-1485

Monday, June 26, 2023 11:14 AM
City Council; City Manager
City Clerk; Rasmussen, Susanne; Shaw, Meghan; Steven Nutter
Perspective on BEUDO, Support from the Climate Committee

To the City Council:
Iâ€™m David Rabkin, a resident living at 184 Huron Avenue and the Chair of the Cityâ€™s Climate Committee.
As an individual and as the Committee Chair, Iâ€™m requesting that tonight you approve BEUDO as is, and not
amend it further.
â€¢ More than 20 years ago, the City created the Climate Protection Action Plan, which recognized the

threat of climate change and called for substantial reductions in the Cityâ€™s overall greenhouse gas
(GHG) emissions.
â€¢ As the years have progressed, our understanding has consistently grown, and so has our assessment of
the increased severity of the consequences of inaction.
â€¢ In 2017, the Council, responding to a lack of progress toward our Cityâ€™s stated goals, passed a policy
order calling for the City as a whole to become â€œnet zeroâ€ with regard to greenhouse gas emissions
by 2035.
â€¢ In 2021, the Commonwealth of Massachusetts passed a law â€“ its Climate Roadmap â€“ which called for
the stateâ€™s overall GHG emissions to be reduced by 50% relative to 1990 levels by 2030.
â€¢ As currently proposed, BEUDERO (BEUDO) targets reducing by 2035 a big chunk, but still far less than
50%, of our cityâ€™s emissions. Itâ€™s a great first step â€“ but only a first step â€“ toward our goals and the
requirements of the laws we face.
â€¢ BEUDO was intended to cover the cityâ€™s large properties â€“ both commercial and residential.
â€¢ The Climate Committee has considered BEUDERO and the current form being considered today many
times. Each time, and over many years, the Committee has argued that BEUDERO should be more
inclusive, not less:
o We have questioned the use of exceptions and/or different schedules for laboratories.
o We have questioned, but now accept, the exemption of condominiums in the short term, and
only because of the ownership structure questions. We note that condos, too, will need to
be weaned from fossil fuel, which will require additional regulation.
o And we have repeatedly recommended that the City consider including MORE residential
properties - not keep the current 50 units and above in BEUDO. Boston sets the limit at
15. Exempting them altogether is inappropriate. They are large, single-owner buildings,
precisely the type of real estate BEUDO should cover.
o Since the Committee has not considered other kinds of exemptions, I canâ€™t comment on them
beyond stating that ultimately we need to regulate ALL our buildings. Why exclude ANY that
fall into the category of larger, single-owner properties, particularly when we have processes
for exemptions relating to financial or technical challenges?
â€¢ BEUDO is going to be complex and challenging to implement. Even if itâ€™s 100% effective, it still targets
less than half of the Cityâ€™s overall emissions. The City needs to stop adding exceptions â€“ which only

Attachment: David Rabkin Perspective on BEUDO Support from the Climate Committee (COM 1539 #2023 : A communication was received from

4.11.a

1

Packet Pg. 512

creates challenges for future policy-making and implementation â€“ and focus on what comes next,
specifically:
o Implementation: We need to provide access to the advisory, technical, and financial services
and tools that property-owners need to respond effectively to BEUDO.
o The rest of our cityâ€™s building stock: Developing the regulations needed to target all the other
kinds of buildings in Cambridge is far from straightforward, and yet itâ€™s essential to reaching
our goals and complying with the laws we and the Commonwealth have passed.
Itâ€™s time to pass BEUDO, shift our focus to the support that property-owners need, and get down to business
on the rest of the emissions-reduction task before us.
Thank you.
David Rabkin
184 Huron Avenue, Climate Committee Chair

Sunday, June 25, 2023 3:45 PM
City Council
City Clerk
BEUDO amendment

Dear Honorable Councillors,
I support the BUEDO amendment by Councillors Toner, Simmons, and McGovern to align condos and rental properties.
While limiting greenhouse gas emissions from commercial buildings is important, treating condos more favorably than
rental units discriminates against tenants, who tend to have lower incomes and will need to pay rent increases. It may
also encourage condo conversions, thus further reducing our rental housing supply. Thank you for your consideration.
David Sullivan
16 Notre Dame Ave., North Cambridge

Attachment: David Sullivan BEUDO amendment (COM 1540 #2023 : A communication was received from David Sullivan)

Please pass a strong version of BEUDO

Dear Mayor and City Councillors,
On June 26 youâ€™ll have a chance to vote on a good policy to cut emissions in our city. The BEUDO Amendments will make
Cambridge healthier and will make our city a leader and an example of appropriate local-level climate action. We know
that we will need a multitude of policies to slow the heating of our planet and that local policies, like BEUDO, have a
central role to play.
I am proud of the work you gave done to craft the version of BEUDO that is before you today, you and the CDD have
worked very hard to reach a good compromise. I think exempting condo owners at this time was a wise choice, just like
favoring local offsets over global ones and setting up a review board with a robust presence of different stakeholders.
Please protect the current version from any attempt to weaken it or granting exemptions. Commercial and institutional
buildings have had a big win when the threshold was raised to 100,000 sf and up. Now itâ€™s time to protect our residents
and our children, whose future is already damaged, from the most catastrophic consequences from climate change.
Please consider a change to make construction after 2024 be netzero by 2030. Development and climate goals need not
be antithetical, but new development canâ€™t continue to rely on fossil fuels and contribute to emissions when we need to
reverse the course.
When there was an air quality alert due to the air pollution from the wildfires in Canada I kept my kids at home instead
of taking them to the playground. No parent wants a future where itâ€™s too hot to be outside, the air is too polluted to
breathe, and thereâ€™s not enough water to grow the food we need.
All children, in Cambridge and everywhere, deserve better. The cost of climate inaction falls squarely on their young
shoulders. Please take responsibility for our climate future by passing strong BEUDO Amendments. Our childrenâ€™s eyes
are looking at you.
Thank you for your leadership
Elena Fagotto , 26 Bigelow st Unit B

Square
Starlight Square Update

Dear Neighbor,
I hope your summer is off to a great start. As Program Director at Central Square BID, I am writing to you with
an update regarding Starlight Square. We have heard your concerns, and we are committed to reducing any
negative impact. As a residential or commercial neighbor, you are on my outreach list - and your participation
and enthusiasm as a community member is key to our seasonâ€™s success.
We are proud to share that Starlight has begun its fourth season of events and performances. We have been
approved by the License Commission of the City of Cambridge for all events thru July 8th. We have also
submitted proposed programming to the License Commission for events happening July 15th thru August 13th.
This application will be heard during the Board of License Commissionersâ€™ Public Meeting on Thursday, July
13th, beginning at 10:30am.
As we have done in the past, a monthly schedule of events has been posted on-site at the corner of Bishop
Allen Drive and Norfolk Street, and on the Starlight Square website (starlightsquare.org/events). We also have
several QR codes posted around the outside of Starlight that link to the public events calendar.
All past sound mitigation efforts are still in place. We reduced the number of performances featuring live drum
kits, and reduced the total number of events by eliminating shows on Tuesday evenings to limit weeknight
impact. We invested in two amplifier shields to help isolate the sound of guitar and bass amps. These shields
have been tested to lower decibel levels from performances. Last season, we implemented several sound
mitigation strategies, which included reducing speakers, installing acoustic panels, investing in a drum shield,
reducing live music events, and ending Sunday performances by 3:00 PM. Our A/V staff will continue to
measure decibel levels multiple times during each event to ensure compliance with the city's noise ordinance.
Do you have any feedback youâ€™d like to share?
If youâ€™d like to share any feedback during an event or otherwise, please contact the on-site manager (Erik,
Danielle, or Carissa) at this phone number: (617) 279-5518. As a neighborhood organization, your input is
important to us. As always, feel free to email me. Expect to hear from me on a monthly basis as we keep an
open dialogue.

Attachment: Erik Sarno Starlight Square Update (COM 1544 #2023 : A communication was received from Erik Sarno)

Taylor, Bernice

In partnership,
Erik
-1

From:

Cc:

Ginger Ryan <gingerryan11@gmail.com>
Friday, June 23, 2023 9:53 AM
City Council
City Clerk; City Manager; Peter Kelsey
Support Strong BEUDO Amendments

Dear City Councillors:
Thank you for your support thus far of a strong set of amendments to the Building Energy Use Disclosure
Ordinance (BEUDO).
We have another hurdle to cross by making these amendments as strong as possible so they reflect the
urgency of the climate crises upon us. We can no longer give a break to owners of large buildings as we seek
to reduce greenhouse gas emissions equitably. Large buildings produce the bulk of the emissions that impact
Cambridge residents and their health.
Therefore, we urge you to include an amendment for a 2030 net zero target for new large labs, scientific
research, and medical facilities. Without this provision, emissions from these buildings could undermine the
greenhouse gas reductions that BEUDO is designed to bring about.
As parents, we want a livable climate now and in the future for all residents. We urge you to pass a final
version of the BEUDO amendments that is as strong as possible to address the urgency of the climate crisis.
With gratitude,
Ginger Ryan and Peter Kelsey
35 Crescent Street
Cambridge, MA 02138

Attachment: Ginger Ryan and Peter Kelsey Support Strong BEUDO Amendments (COM 1546 #2023 : A communication was received from

Taylor, Bernice

Please Support a Strong Set of BEUDO amendments

Dear City Councillors:
Thank you so much for your combined vision, energy, and commitment that has resulted in a strong set of
amendments to the Building Energy Use Disclosure Ordinance (BEUDO), which will come before the Council
on Monday, June 26.
As my twenty-three-year-old daughter, Emily, raised in Cambridge, is setting off on her adult life, I worry a
great deal about the state of the world she is inheriting, an unstable world marked by record ocean warmth,
record low reservoirs in the West, and record wildfires, storms, and floods. And I worry about children and
families right here in Cambridge who suffer from asthma, the effects of extreme heat, and other issues related
to climate and the burning of fossil fuels.
The BEUDO amendments will have a significant impact in moving us toward our Net Zero goals as a city. They
are, in fact, essential.
Thank you again for everything you've done so far. I urge you to follow through on Monday by passing a final
version of the BEUDO amendments that is strong, vigorous, and adequate to the urgency at hand.
Thank you,
Hannah Mahoney

Azeem, Burhan; Carlone, Dennis; Mallon, Alanna; McGovern, Marc; Nolan, Patricia;
Siddiqui, Sumbul; Simmons, Denise; Toner, Paul; Zondervan, Quinton; City Manager
City Clerk
Please exempt large rental housing from BEUDO 2035 retrofit timeline

Dear Members of the Cambridge City Council and City Manager Huang,
We understand that an amendment will be offered at the June 26th City Council meeting to exempt large
rental housing from the BEUDO 2035 retrofit timeline. I urge you to adopt this amendment. The existing 2035
timeline will cause displacement of residents in order to rush through the retrofits; it will also cause higher
rents to pay for the retrofits.
The City Council has many laudable goals. Unfortunately some of these goals are in conflict. Rushing through
residential retrofits will conflict with maintaining our already inadequate supply of affordable housing.
Maintaining our housing supply must take precedence. Remember that the April 12 City Councillor BEUDO Q &
A document opined that â€œEven a limited scope project could require relocation of occupants for up to a yearâ€
(page 2) .
I urge the Council to take the time to study what level of retrofits can be done without displacing residents,
and to locate funding sources that are substantial enough for the task at hand (tens of thousands of dollars
per rental unit). In the meantime, please assign large rental housing to the 2050 timeline.
With many thanks for your consideration,
Helen Walker
43 Linnaean Street
(617) 491-4998

From:

Jack Hanson <jack@runonclimate.org>
Sunday, June 25, 2023 6:16 PM
Siddiqui, Sumbul; Mallon, Alanna; Simmons, Denise; Toner, Paul; Carlone, Dennis;
McGovern, Marc; Azeem, Burhan; Nolan, Patricia; Zondervan, Quinton; Farooq, Iram;
Huang, Yi-An; City Clerk
Critical Climate Votes on Monday

Dear Mayor Siddiqui, Vice Mayor Mallon, and City Councilors,
My name is Jack Hanson and I'm the Executive Director of Run On Climate and a former City Councilor in Burlington,
Vermont. I've written to you previously on votes to advance climate action in Cambridge.
You have a great opportunity tomorrow to make progress on the most consequential issue of our time -- the climate
crisis -- while simultaneously helping make your community safer, more affordable, and more resilient.
What you all do in Cambridge matters well beyond the direct impacts. The policies you are voting on serve as both an
inspiration and a model for communities across the country.
Our work at Run On Climate is to accelerate municipal climate action and spread the most effective municipal climate
policies to jurisdictions across the U.S. I can tell you with certainty that Cambridge is among a small handful of leading
municipalities.
Tomorrow you have the chance to pass cutting edge policy that will help push forward and shape climate action across
this country.
Decarbonizing buildings is one of the greatest challenges of our time, and Cambridge is poised to lead the way. Please
vote yes on the BEUDO amendments without any changes that would weaken them. Please also vote yes to move
forward on prohibiting fossil fuels in newly constructed buildings. This is, from my perspective, a no-brainer and should
be adopted swiftly.
Thank you for reading and please reach out any time if you would like to discuss further.
Sincerely,
Jack Hanson
Executive Director
Run On Climate
847-641-0175

4.23.a

From:

Joan Pickett <jpickett7@yahoo.com>
Sunday, June 25, 2023 5:03 PM
Nolan, Patricia; McGovern, Marc; Mallon, Alanna; Zondervan, Quinton; City Council; City
Clerk; City Manager; Farooq, Iram
PO#5: NO MORE DELAY in Economic Impact assessment

Dear Councillors Nolan, Mallon, Zondervan and McGovern,
I am writing about PO#5 which you have put forward. I am surprised by the timing and, unfortunately,
I must question your motives.
The business community has waited well over a year for something the Council promised to do in
February 2022---- conduct an economic impact assessment of CSO separated bike lanes on
businesses. It took well over a year for CDD to find and hire a consultant, Volpe Transportation. The
contract and approach was recently reviewed at Councillor Toner's economic development
committee. Councillor Nolan is the only PO sponsor that participated and did not raise concerns
about approach or suggest any of the content now in the PO.
We all want to ensure the study is as accurate and meaningful as possible, and perhaps the PO
content adds value to that goal. I am sure this is the rationale you will provide at the council meeting.
However, the timing is suspect given the the consultant has already begun work and CDD's goal is to
have the study completed in the fall. Over the past year, you had plenty of time to offer your
suggestions, as well as those of your advisors, on approach to the CM and CDD as the RFP was
developed.
Unless there is a definitive Yes answer that the PO content can be incorporated into the existing
Volpe contract without creating a delay, it should not pass. Or, would passage of this PO mean the
consultant selection process needs to be re-bid as this seems to be a material change in project
scope as well as approach? For sure, the price tag just increased. It would be very unfortunate if this
PO created any further delay rather than provide an outcome enhancement.
It is disheartening to see the continued lack of support and understanding from the council for our
small businesses and their situation. They have waited over a year for the study to even be kicked off
and now this wrench is thrown into the discussion. Please, no more delays.
Sincerely,
Joan Pickett
59 Ellery St.

Attachment: Joan Pickett PO#5 NO MORE DELAY in Economic Impact assessment (COM 1551 #2023 : A communication was received from

Taylor, Bernice

Monday, June 26, 2023 11:49 AM
City Council; City Clerk; City Manager
Support BEUDO Amendment

Dear City Councillors,
Please support the amendment to exempt large apartment buildings and to allow houses of worship and
hospitals extra special consideration as well as historic buildings. It is common sense to make these changes
now before passing the Ordinance. Large apartment building owners will pass along the cost of retrofitting their
buildings to tenants further exasperating our housing challenges. Religious organizations are already facing
significant financial challenges. Why should the city add to them with the full knowledge now they will be
unable to afford retrofitting their buildings?
The goals of BEUDO are laudable but please consider impacts on those that are smaller contributors to the
problem and the spill over impacts which run counter to other city goals. Make changes to the Ordinance now
before it passes.
Sincerely,
Joan Pickett
59 Ellery St

City Council; City Manager; City Clerk
VOTE NO PO109 - Increasing the scope of impact study does not work

Vote NO on PO109 about the business survey. While I share your frustra on about the lack of a business impact analysis,
increasing the study's scope and complexity will make things much worse and assure failure. To deliver on large,
complex projects, you must focus on the problem you wish to solve rather than "boiling the ocean." A be er approach
would narrow and subdivide the study into smaller 'bites' that can be achieved successfully in a predictable me frame.
To that end, we should limit our focus to 5â€7 years of data and a few speciï¬c CSO sites. If we ï¬gure out a good model,
we can expand in a subsequent phase to other areas and be er understand the best data to collect going forward.
You never have exactly the data you think you need at the beginning. e.g., tax returns of all businesses (which is a
privacy issue). An analysis requires some crea vity to answer the speciï¬c ques ons we have. We should focus on a few
though ul ques ons. The City Council's me is be er spent deï¬ning these ques ons than dicta ng the analysis
methods.
Finally, the recently published business survey results provide their essen al and clear concerns. The survey design was
subop mal but did give insights. In the absence of other data, the business owners voiced signiï¬cant dissa sfac on with
parking, traï¬ƒc, and the cost of space. These points should not be ignored as 'subjec ve.' Even though the survey
included businesses with private parking, 70% of respondents rated these issues as major concerns.
Vote No. Focus, focus, focus.
John Hanra y
Mount Vernon Street, Cambridge

allow only 10 percent of emissions to be compensated for by carbon oï¬€sets, and the Commonwealth of Massachuse s
up to 15 percent. Strict limits on oï¬€set use are essen al, given the dubious and o en counterproduc ve record of global
oï¬€sets.

Kelly Dolan <kelly.dolan.kd@gmail.com>
Saturday, June 24, 2023 2:52 PM
City Clerk; City Manager; City Council
Policy Order #5 Business Impact Study

The city of Cambridge should enlist the involvement of the MIT Urban Planning Department to conduct the Impact Study
for the bike lanes instead of trying to hire an outside independent company.
Cambridge is investing an extensive amount of money in bike lanes that are reshaping our entire city without any pre or
post analysis for their impacts.
Almost all of the really good existing economic impact studies have been written by university professionals who know
how to effectively aggregate and conduct such projects, especially one that will take years to complete.
Currently there is very little trust between the small business community and the city. Having a local university with
strong ties to our community would be a much better option than utilizing an outside firm being paid by the city.
Sincerely
Kelly Dolan
Upland Road
--

awards/designations!

happy to have given birth to and raised our two boys in Cambridge even though it has not always been easy for us
financially. There were always so many great free events to take our kids to and so much help when we needed it,
sometimes from many of you. I sent my boys the link to the â€œBest Place to live for familiesâ€ and said â€œYouâ€™re Welcome!â€

boston25news.com

As an environmentalist I have been a part of the push to demand you do more but I have always appreciated how hard
you work and care for this city and the people who live and work in it, how well this city runs, how easy it is to get what
we need from various city departments and that you are continually striving to do more, so congratulations and thank
you.

Kristine Jelstrup

Kristine Jelstrup <kejelstrup@gmail.com>
Monday, June 26, 2023 10:20 AM
City Council; City Manager
City Clerk
Comments to City Council on Ordinance #26 - BEUDO Amendments

Honorable City Councillors:
First of all, thank you so much for your support thus far of a strong set of amendments to the Building Energy Use
Disclosure Ordinance (BEUDO).
I think by now we are all aware that the climate crisis is barreling down upon us fast. Most of us can now see, feel,
smell and personally experience it almost every day of the year. The climate crisis is of course not an issue that
Cambridge alone can solve but we must act in good faith and follow a moral compass that dictates we do our best.
By helping to reduce the CO2 levels in Cambridge, stronger BEUDO amendments are a great step in the right
direction. So I urge you to pass the strongest amendments possible!
Please do not vote to exempt houses of worship, health centers or hospitals. This has the possibility of creating
large loopholes. We need to keep exemptions to attributes like technical or financial feasibility. The BEUDO Review
Board should be able to evaluate exemptions requests on a case-by-case basis. I urge you also to not vote to
exempt residential buildings. The CDD was clear that we need to ensure that residential buildings start the process
of recognizing they need to decarbonize. Simply having residents switch to 100% renewable electricity will get most
of them to their goal.
Lastly, I support the inclusion of a 2030 net zero target for new large lab, scientific research, and medical facilities.
Without this provision, emissions from these buildings could undermine the greenhouse gas reductions that BEUDO
is designed to bring about. We must ALL be working together on our goal of reaching Net Zero. How can we
possibly hope to achieve that if we exempt so many players?
Again, my sincerest gratitude for all you do on a daily basis trying to achieve our climate goals as a city and to do
our part for the global community.
Kristine Jelstrup
126 Prospect Street
Mothers Out Front Member

Disclosure Ordinance (BEUDO).
I think by now we are all aware that the climate crisis is barreling down upon us fast. Most of us can now see, feel, smell
and personally experience it almost every day of the year. The climate crisis is of course not an issue that Cambridge
alone can solve but we must act in good faith and follow a moral compass that dictates we do our best. By helping to

to pass the strongest amendments possible!

From:
