forward to new ventures. I remember Vice Mayor Alanna's enthusiastic support of Walk for Hunger going back to
2018. Looking through old email exchanges with her, it saddens me to note that In 2017, 11 funded agencies in
Cambridge received $41,700. Although the hunger insecurity persists, due to new ways of allocating funds, the City
received 1/10 of that amount. But I am sure other agencies received grants directly through the new procedure. I will
adjust my strategy for soliciting support in accordance with the new procedure.
Respectfully yours,
Young Kim

Young Kim

Todayâ€™s agenda for the last City Council meeting before the summer break is a story of two cities. On
one hand, we are ending on a high note of City Manager Agenda Item #7 announcing four-thousanddollar grant awarded to the Summer Food Program from the Project Bread. I want to thank publicly the
generous community support for the Kids Fighting Against Hunger Team led by 5-year-old cocaptain Ileana and her 20 months old sister Kamala of Norris Street. We were proud to have raised
$4055, just little over the grant we received!
On the other hand, we are ending on a low note of Policy Order #5, that "the City Manager is requested
to consider measures to improve the Cycling Safety Ordinance Business Impact Study." Please do not
adopt this policy order for the reasons I have amply documented in my letter to you this morning but
donâ€™t have the time to present to you during this short comment time. I would welcome an opportunity
to present them at a separate meeting. Please donâ€™t consider this Policy Order only by itself but in
conjunction with the contract with Volpe Center for the Study and the CDDâ€™s presentation to the
Economic Development & University Relations Committee Meeting on May 2, 2023. By the deadline for
the City Managerâ€™s report in this order, Volpe Center would have delivered Final Deliverables for Task 4 Finalize Report & Data Summary Template on 8/10/2023. So, is this Policy Order requesting the City
Manager to start the study again from the beginning?
The Volpe Center contract is yet another case for my call for an audit of CSO implementation. The
contract points to the way the Purchasing Department constructs a contract with making sure all the Iâ€™s
are dotted and all the tâ€™s are crossed. In the case of the Economic Study contract, the City missed
inconsistent deliverable schedule in the Statement of Work and didnâ€™t even assign a Cambridge
Purchasing Departmentâ€™s file number.
Thank you

Taylor, Bernice

Young Kim <ycknorris@gmail.com>
Monday, June 26, 2023 8:26 AM
Siddiqui, Sumbul; Mallon, Alanna; Azeem, Burhan; Carlone, Dennis; McGovern, Marc;
Nolan, Patricia; Simmons, Denise; Toner, Paul; Zondervan, Quinton; City Clerk

McKenna, Brooke; Watkins, Kathy; Cambridge Charter Review Committee; McCann,
Joseph
Reject Policy Order #5 re measures to improve the CSO Business Impact Study
Letter Economic Committee Hearing 5_2.pdf; Post 5_2_Committee Meeting Letter to
Chair Toner.pdf; [P230599] Fully Executed Volpe Agreement No.VP140023_Redacted
(1).pdf

Dear Mayor, City Councillors and City Clerk,
Please reject Policy Order #5, that "the City Manager is requested to consider measures to improve the
Cycling Safety Ordinance Business Impact Study" for the reasons I have amply documented in my
correspondences on this matter forwarded below and in the two attachments. Please note that I incorrectly
identified Councillor Toner as one of the sponsors of POR 2021 #259 in Post 5_2_Committee Meeting Letter to
Chair Toner. That should have been former Councillor Toomey.
I am also attaching Volpe Agreement No. VP140023 for your reference.
Please consider the following before you debate this Policy Order (PO):

1. City signed
in spite of the fact
that the due dates for the deliverables in the text of the Task description are not consistent with the dates in
the summary table in the Statement Of Work. And please note that the Agreement has Volpe Center file
number and not the Cambridge's. My repeated request to the Public Records Access Officer for the Request for
Proposal and list of bidders have not been responded to.
2. The Contract is a "Best Effort (not fixed price), no fee basis" contract. So what is the consequence of this PO on
this contract if adopted?
3. Cycling Safety Ordinance (CSO) Economic Impact Study Update presented by Community Development
Department (CDD) to the Economic Development & University Relations Committee Meeting on May 2, 2023
seems to be consistent with Deliverables for Task 1, Develop Study Methodology & Finalize Economic Data Set
which was due almost 3 months earlier on 2/10/2023 assuming 1/10/2023 start (i.e. City advanced the
estimated cost of $100,000 upon approval of the Agreement per the Contract)
4. According to the Deliverable Schedule, by now Volpe Center should be wrapping up a draft of the Finalize Report
& Data Summary Template due on 7/10/2023.
5. This PO is requesting the City Manager to "report back to the City Council on these matters by September 1,
2023, outlining the proposed improvements to the business impact study for separated bicycle lanes, including
the incorporation of objective data sources, collaboration with external partners, and strategies for gathering

Attachment: Young Kim Reject Policy Order #5 re measures to improve the CSO Business Impact Study (COM 1596 #2023 : A communication

4.68.a

1

Packet Pg. 741

feedback and ideas from businesses." But Volpe Center would have delivered Final Deliverables for Task 4 Finalize Report & Data Summary Template on 8/10/2023. So, is this PO requesting the CM to go back to Task
1? And what consequences will that have on the Contract with Volpe?
6. The public has the right to know what transpired since the CSO Impact Study Update presentation by CDD on
May 2, 2023 to warrant this apparent restart. I, for one, demand an explanation and demand an audit of CSO
Implementation by the City Auditor who reports directly to the City Council, as I have been asking in previous
communications.
Thank you for your consideration,
Respectfully yours,
Young Kim
Norris Street

Dear Chairman Toner,
Thank you for getting the Community Development Department (CDD) presentations on the Agenda Packet and thank
you and your committee for reporting back on your meeting.
However, I am totally disappointed and deeply concerned. The City Council accepting your Committee's report without
any discussion proves, yet again, how desperately we need reforms in the City governance. The two reports from CDD
should not have been accepted in the first place by your Committee let alone reporting back to the City Council.
Through you, please require CDD to provide documents highlighted and in bold red below. Furthermore, from now on,
any report from the City departments to the City Council that are based on outside contractors should include
deliverable schedules and delivered documents as I am constantly finding City reports are one step behind what the
contractors are doing. The City is presenting their version of the delivered documents to the community to gather
feedback when in fact the City has already accepted the contractor's deliverables and had given them permission to
proceed. This is my observation based on public records I have obtained through 29 (and counting) Public Records
Requests and even appealing to the State Public Records Office on some of the denied requests.
According to the minutes of the City Council on 5/15/2023:
